sentences_tone.text: Tesla Is Slowly Admitting Supercharging Costs Thousands Of Dollars Per Car - Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksTesla Is Slowly Admitting Supercharging Costs Thousands Of Dollars Per CarNov.11.16 | About: Tesla Motors (TSLA) Alberto Zaragoza Comendador Follow Gadgets, utilities, oil & gas, carmakersSend MessageSummaryCompany statements and data on Supercharger cost and utilization are analyzed.Unavoidable conclusion is that, over a typical 15-20 year car life, free Supercharging costs Tesla thousands of dollars.The company has budgeted only a small part of this committed cost.Ahead of schedule for once: Tesla drops free Supercharging 80% before target.NOTE: All the numbers and charts used in this article can be seen in this Excel.
If the link stops working please send me a private message or leave a comment.
When it comes to Superchargers, Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) has never disclosed exactly how much they cost to build and operate.
This can lead to confusion.

The company's statements could make an investor (or any reader, really) believe that the feature costs about $500 per car, but that is not the case at all: When you actually do the math, you discover the real cost is thousands of dollars per car.
Since Tesla seems unwilling to clear up the misunderstanding, I will.
Cars vs. dollars Tesla considers Supercharging a deliverable, which is to say a service that the customer has paid for, but which the company hasn't (yet) provided.
For this reason, instead of recognizing all the revenue upfront when a car is sold, Tesla defers (allocates, reserves) part to cover the costs of Supercharging down the road.
Thus, as time goes by, this deferred revenue is gradually recognized, or accreted in accounting parlance.
In layman's terms, the deferred revenue becomes current revenue in the company's income statement.
Ideally, as time goes by, this revenue should match the costs of running the Supercharger network.

However, if deferred revenue is less than the costs of Supercharging, one could say Tesla is underestimating the latter; the company would be reserving less money than is needed to pay for this service.
The first obvious step is to look at how much revenue has been deferred per car.
To figure out how many Teslas have the right to use the Supercharger network, we take a look at the company's cumulative deliveries.

Virtually all Teslas sold since 2012 have the ability to Supercharge, and although some cars have been lost to accidents or are for some other reason no longer on the road, the fleet is young enough (under 2 years old on average) that we can ignore attrition.
Here you can see how the number of cars delivered has scaled pretty much in line with revenue deferred to pay for the service.
For every additional 20,000 cars, revenue deferred increases by $10 million; thus, $500 per car seems a good estimate for the cost of this feature.
So it all seems jolly good.
But there is a very big problem with this graph: The cumulative figure can be hiding a deviation in some particular quarters.
It's probably more interesting to see how much revenue is deferred per car, not just cumulatively but quarter by quarter.
How can we know that?
Tesla only discloses the amount of revenue deferred by the end of a given quarter, without saying how much was recognized over the period.
Imagine revenue deferred at the end of March is $1 million, and at the end of June, it's also $1 million.
Would you conclude that cars delivered in April-June had $0 of deferred revenue?
No: What happened is that the 'pot' was on the one hand, diminished by revenue that was recognized over that quarter, and on the other hand, increased by revenue from cars sold during that period.
So if you want to know how much revenue was deferred in any particular quarter, you cannot simply take the difference in outstanding revenue at the end of two quarters.
You have to add an estimate of how much revenue was recognized during the quarter.
Tesla discloses that the recognition period is 8 years, or 32 quarters, so it's easy to do the math.
Here you can see the result.
While the cumulative or total figure is indeed about $500 (though trending up), the last four quarters have seen a massive spike, finishing at $833.
Those who are used to seeing graphs will notice something odd: If orange represents the latest quarter and blue the cumulative, why doesn't blue always follow orange?
Their connection seems very loose.
Compare 14Q2 with 16Q2: Over a period of 2 years, the 'latest' stayed above the 'cumulative' most of the time (and when it didn't, they were basically at the same level).
If the latest really led the cumulative, then the latter should have increased over the period - instead it barely budged.
Well, there is a problem with the cumulative line: We're simply dividing revenue deferred by total deliveries.
Tesla defers enough revenue to cover 8 years of Supercharging (we'll get back to that).
The money deferred is, thus, enough to pay for Supercharging until the average cars is 8 years old; deferred revenue should decline gradually and reach $0 the day that happens.
But the average car is not 0 years old at the moment!
In other words, the $84.7 million that Tesla's deferred pot had by the end of September does not cover an additional 8 years.
Rather, it will cover 8 years minus whatever the average age of the cars is.
For example, I estimate that by the end of September, the average Tesla on the road was 16.7 months old (details in the Excel).
Remember, 8 years is 96 months, so Tesla expects the average car to use the Superchargers for another 96 - 16.7 = 79.3 months.
So those $84.7 million cover an additional 79.3 months for the average car, not an additional 96.
It's worth asking, then, what is the implicit cost for 96 months.
For 2016Q3, the simple method gave a figure of $525 per car; since 96 / 79.3 = 1.21, we have to increase this by 21%.
After accounting for that, it turns out that Tesla expects the average car to cost $635 over 8 years.
After repeating the count for every quarter, we get a cumulative line that seems to match the figures for the latest quarter much better.
'So what?
It's just a $333 difference' It's indeed a $333 difference until you remember that Tesla is recognizing revenue over a period of eight years.

Look inside any of their 10-Qs and you will find this (emphasis added): 'Automotive revenue includes revenues related to deliveries of new vehicles, sales of regulatory credits to other automotive manufacturers, and specific other elements that meet the definition of a deliverable under multiple-element accounting guidance including free internet connectivity, free access to our Supercharger network, and free future over the air software updates.

These deliverables are valued on a stand-alone basis and we recognize their revenue over our performance period, which is generally the eight-year life of the vehicle, except for internet connectivity which is over the free four year period.'

Yes, these cars have been promised free Supercharging for life, and the company is supposedly aiming for a million-mile powertrain, and fans talk about 500,000-mile battery packs, but somehow they estimate that people will only use the charging network for eight years.
After that everybody delivers his car to a museum, I guess.
It seems more reasonable to assume people will keep and drive their cars for 15-20 years; after all the average auto on US roads is 11.5 years old.
For the purpose of simplicity, let's double the figures Tesla states: from $500 to $1,000, from $833 to $1,666.
'So what?
It's just a $666 difference' It's only a $666 difference until you remember that the revenue deferred does not cover all the costs of Supercharging.
It's only the portion allocated to cost of goods sold (COGS), or gross costs, or 'cost of revenues' as Tesla prefers to call it.

Per its letter to the SEC: 'Because we do not spend money on traditional advertising and consider our Supercharger network as our only major marketing effort from a business perspective, we recorded a portion of the costs related to our Supercharger network to cost of automotive sales and another portion to selling, general and administrative expense.
This allocation was based on expected usage levels at Supercharger locations.

Generally speaking, Superchargers located on more frequently traveled routes with eight or more charging stations were those that we estimated would have a higher utilization rate and are recorded to cost of automotive sales.
Supercharger stations expected to have low utilization rates serve more as a marketing function for Tesla and we recorded these costs to selling, general and administrative.
As of December 31, 2013, we allocated 40% of our Supercharger network costs to cost of automotive sales and the remaining 60% to selling, general and administrative.'
Stunningly, this fact has not been disclosed anywhere else.

Yes, the company's language in its quarterly reports implies that some Supercharging costs are allocated to SG&A, rather than gross costs; but it seems striking that Tesla would disclose the amount of revenue deferred and not the SG&A portion, when in fact, the latter is a much bigger part of the cost.
So let's do the math.
Tesla has typically deferred $500 to pay for Supercharging, but as of December 31st, 2013, this covered only 40% of total costs - meaning actual costs were $1,250 per car.

Applying the same ratio to the latest figures we have: · If you take the cumulative revenue deferred per car ($635), then Supercharging costs are $1,587 for an 8-year period, or $3,175 for a more realistic period.
· If you take the revenue deferred per car only for the latest quarter ($833), then total Supercharging costs are $2,082 for an 8-year period, or $4,165 for a more realistic period.
Obviously, neither of these numbers is exactly close to $500.
One thing about the rest of the article: 'deferred revenue' is supposed to match this gross cost, or COGS, or cost of revenues.
So these four terms will be used interchangeably.
'But you're just assuming the COGS-to-SG&A ratio is the same as it was in 2013' Fair point: In my last two articles, I did exactly that.
Conceivably, deferred revenue could have gone from 40% to, say 50% of total Supercharging costs.
That would mean my previous figures are an overestimate: Rather than multiplying $635 and $833 by 2.5, I should have multiplied them by 2, or perhaps less - there's no way to know for sure.
So I emailed Tesla on Thursday, November 3 asking what is the current COGS/SG&A split.
No response.
And then I decided to actually count how many Superchargers, as of the end of September 2016, had 8 stalls or more.
Since this is 'generally speaking' the basis that Tesla uses to determine how to classify costs, I figured looking at this could help.

(I haven't gotten around to doing the same count for 2013 because a lot of the stations opened during or before that year have been expanded, so one has to be careful to use the number of stalls that the stations actually had back then)
The result is that stations with 8 or more stalls account for:
38% of all stations 52.8% of all stalls
You would expect a bigger station to cost more on an absolute basis, but less on a per-stall basis.
For example, if a station with a single charger (2 stalls) has a malfunction, the whole site goes offline and Tesla has to fix it quickly.
By contrast, a malfunction in a station with 4 chargers is not nearly as urgent.
Economies of scale probably apply to charging stations just as they apply to most of everything we do.

So it seems reasonable that the cost of running these stations, which is (according to Tesla) more or less equivalent to the COGS portion, might have been somewhere between 38% and 52.8% of the total Supercharging cost.
Let's say 45%, rather than 40%.
This wouldn't really change the numbers I showed in the previous section - it would make them 11% smaller, but still several times bigger than $500.
But I don't believe that's true; if anything, the portion of Supercharging costs covered by deferred revenue has probably declined since 2013.
Read on.
Tesla's implied Supercharging costs seem too low, not too high Let's try and estimate not how much revenue Tesla defers per car, but how much it costs to actually run the Supercharger network.

There are two kinds of costs:
Operating: Electricity, maintenance, leases (Tesla generally does not own the land the Superchargers and Service Centers are built on) Capital costs: This is the actual cost of building the network.

If you have heard that a cost is 'capitalized', it means that a company does not count the expense of building stuff upfront; rather a part of the cost is counted in each period the asset will be in use.
So to know this cost, we need to know the period over which the Superchargers will be in use, i.e. the depreciation period.
Hence capital expenses are also called depreciation or amortization costs (these terms will be used interchangeably).
It turns out we can more or less estimate depreciation costs, which will give us a minimum estimate of total costs; we also know at least something about operating expenses.
In this part of the article, I will compare these expenses with the revenue Tesla defers per car.
I will show it's impossible for this deferred revenue to make up more than 40% of total Supercharging costs.

First of all, one must keep in mind that the costs incurred during a given quarter are not only due to cars sold that quarter; rather, costs arise because all cars sold until that moment use the network.
So to calculate the costs corresponding to 15Q1, 15Q2, etc., we use the cumulative revenue deferred per car, i.e. the blue line in the article's third chart.
Okay, what do we do with that blue line?
It gives a cost per car, which we can translate into a cost per car-quarter.

If we can also calculate how many car-quarters have gone by in any given quarter (again, the specific calculation is available in the Excel), then we can know the COGS portion of Supercharging costs for a given quarter.
Or, at least, what Tesla estimates it to be.
I will put it in a graph in orange.

But first, take a look again at the company's letter to the SEC: 'Supercharger equipment is depreciated over an estimated useful life of 12 years and infrastructure improvement costs are depreciated over the shorter of the lease term of the Supercharger site or five years.'
